raw_text:
Young debut cut short by Ginepri
 
 Fifteen-year-old Donald Young's first appearance in an ATP tennis tournament proved brief as the teenager went out in round one of the San Jose Open.
 
 Young shot to the top of the junior world rankings when he won the boys' singles at January's Australian Open. But the wildcard entry was dispatched by fellow American Robby Ginepri in straight sets, 6-2 6-2, in California. Despite that he was happy with his Tour debut. "It was fun. I had my chances, but they didn't come through," he said. Young, who beat two players ranked in the top 200 when he was just 14, was only 2-1 down in the first set before losing 10 of the next 13 games. And Ginepri - six years older than the youngest player to ever win a junior slam and top the global standings - admitted he was impressed.
 
 "He's very talented," said Ginepri. "He's got a long future ahead of him. "Being left-handed, he was very quick around the court. "His serve is a little deceptive. He came into the net and volleyed better than I thought." Earlier, South Korean Hyung-Taik Lee defeated American Jan-Michael Gambill 6-3 7-6 (7-4). American Kevin Kim defeated Jan Hernych of the Czech Republic 7-5 6-3, Canadian qualifier Frank Dancevic downed American Jeff Morrison 4-6 7-6 (7-3) 6-0, and Denmark's Kenneth Carlsen beat Irakli Labadze of the Republic of Georgia 6-7 (4-7) 6-2 6-3. Top seed Andy Roddick launches his defence of the title on Wednesday against qualifier Paul Goldstein. Second seed Andre Agassi opens his campaign on Tuesday against wildcard Bobby Reynolds, last year's US collegiate champion. Agassi has won the San Jose five times, but his run of three straight titles ended last year when he fell to Mardy Fish in the semi-finals. Fish went on to lose to Roddick in the final.
llama3.2:1b: Donald Young made his ATP tennis tournament debut at age 15, losing to Robby Ginepri in round one of the San Jose Open.
Despite being young and talented, Young was outplayed by Ginepri in straight sets (6-2, 6-2).
Ginepri praised Young's quickness around the court and deceptive serve.
llama3.2:3b: Donald Young lost in round one of the San Jose Open to Robby Ginepri 6-2, 6-2, his first ATP tournament appearance.
Young was ranked high as a junior and beat two top 200 players at age 14.
Despite this, he was happy with the experience and praised Ginepri's skills.
gemma2:2b: Donald Young was defeated in the first round of the San Jose Open by Robby Ginepri.
Despite losing, Young impressed with his talent and speed.
Other notable matches involved Hyung-Taik Lee, Kevin Kim, Frank Dancevic, and Kenneth Carlsen.
Top seeds Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi will begin their tournament runs on Wednesday and Tuesday, respectively.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A 15-year-old American named Donald Young first played a tennis match in junior tournaments at age 14.
He lost the game in just one round against Robby Ginepri, who was younger than him and had won some big matches before.
Ginepri was impressed with Young's talent but was disappointed that he didn't win even though it was his first time playing a major tournament.
Young beat two other players ranked in the top 200 at age 14 before losing to another player named Ginepri later in the year.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Teenage debut ends for Donald Young at 15 years old, losing to Robby Ginepri in the first round of the San Jose Open due to age difference and poor performance.
2-100 in juniors but struggled against older wildcard.
Also reports on other junior matches including a win by Hyung-Taik Lee over American Jan-Michael Gambill.

Despite early promise, Young was outplayed in straight sets (6-2 6-2).
Young had previously beaten two top-200 players at age 14.
Ginepri praised Young's talent and quickness but noted his deceptive serve.
Other matches included South Korean Lee defeating Gambill, Kevin Kim beating Hernych, Frank Dancevic defeating Morrison, and Kenneth Carlsen overcoming Irakli Labadze.
Andy Roddick defends title, Andre Agassi opens tournament campaign.
opencoder:1.5b: "The young Ginepri played the game with a passion and determination as he continued to improve over time, learning from his mistakes and growing closer to the top players."
smollm:1.7b: Young debut cut short by Ginepri
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Donald Young (from South Korea) made a debut in an ATP tennis tournament at the San Jose Open, winning the boys' singles but falling to another American player, Ginepri, in straight sets 6-2/6-2.
Despite his talent, he was down 2-1 after losing only two points in the first set and struggling in subsequent games.
Ginepri, six years older than the youngest junior champion and top globally ranked, impressed with Young's skills despite being left-handed.
The match highlighted the contrast between young talent and established players.
tinyllama:1.1b: The fifteen-year-old Donald Young made a brief appearance in an ATP tennis tournament, where he won against fellow American Robby Ginepri in straight sets before losing 10 of the next 13 games.
However, despite being down 2-1 in the first set, Young was impressive and showed his talent throughout the match.
His opponent Giinepri, who had already reached the top ranking, also commented that he was impressed by Young's performance.
The youngest player to win a junior title and ranked as high as #200 at the time of the tournament, Young will face top seed Andy Roddick in the second round.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The young tennis player Donald Young made a brief appearance in the ATP tennis tournament but was defeated by fellow American Robby Ginepri in straight sets.
Despite his disappointing loss, Young expressed his enjoyment of his time on the Tour and credited it to his impressive junior rankings.
